subject: Biology
description: Campbell Biology Chapter 38 – Angiosperm Reproduction and Biotechnology: flower structure, gametophyte development, pollination, double fertilization, seed development, fruit development, and plant biotechnology (IBO/USABO/NSEB level)

questions.question: In angiosperms, the female gametophyte (embryo sac) typically develops through megasporogenesis and megagametogenesis. What is the fate of the four megaspores produced by meiosis of the megaspore mother cell in the Polygonum-type embryo sac?
options: All four megaspores undergo mitosis to form a multicellular gametophyte
All four megaspores are released as microspores that develop into pollen grains
Two megaspores fuse to form a diploid central cell, and the other two form synergids
Three megaspores degenerate, and the surviving functional megaspore undergoes three rounds of mitosis to produce an 8-nucleate, 7-celled embryo sac
questions.explanation: In the Polygonum-type embryo sac (the most common pattern, found in approximately 70% of angiosperms), the megaspore mother cell (megasporocyte, 2n) undergoes meiosis to produce four haploid megaspores arranged in a linear tetrad. Three of these megaspores (typically the three closest to the micropyle) degenerate through programmed cell death. The single surviving functional megaspore (usually the chalazal-most) undergoes three consecutive rounds of mitosis without cytokinesis, producing an 8-nucleate coenocyte. Subsequent cellularization creates the 7-celled embryo sac: 3 antipodal cells at the chalazal end, 2 synergids flanking the egg cell at the micropylar end, the egg cell itself, and the large central cell containing 2 polar nuclei. The synergids play crucial roles in pollen tube guidance through secretion of attractant peptides (LURE proteins), and the central cell's polar nuclei will fuse with one sperm during double fertilization to form the triploid endosperm.

questions.question: Double fertilization is a defining feature of angiosperms. What are the two fertilization events, and what is the ploidy of the resulting tissues?
options: One sperm fuses with the egg (producing a 2n zygote) and one sperm fuses with one synergid (producing a 2n accessory embryo)
One sperm fertilizes the egg and the other sperm is stored in the antipodal cells for delayed fertilization in case of embryo failure
Both sperm fuse with the egg simultaneously, producing a tetraploid embryo
One sperm fuses with the egg (producing a 2n zygote) and one sperm fuses with the two polar nuclei in the central cell (producing a 3n endosperm)
questions.explanation: Double fertilization involves two simultaneous fertilization events within the embryo sac. One sperm cell fuses with the egg cell (n), producing a diploid (2n) zygote that develops into the embryo. The second sperm cell fuses with the two polar nuclei (each n) in the central cell, producing a triploid (3n) primary endosperm nucleus that develops into the endosperm—the nutritive tissue that supports embryo development and, in many species, provides nutrition for the germinating seedling. This process is unique to angiosperms (and Ephedra among gymnosperms, though with different outcomes). The triploid endosperm is genetically 2:1 maternal to paternal, which has implications for genomic imprinting. Double fertilization ensures that endosperm develops only when fertilization occurs, preventing wasteful investment in nutritive tissue without a viable embryo. The synergids facilitate pollen tube reception and burst, and the antipodal cells may have nutritive functions but are not fertilized.

questions.question: Self-incompatibility (SI) in angiosperms prevents inbreeding by rejecting self-pollen. In the sporophytic self-incompatibility (SSI) system found in Brassicaceae, what determines pollen compatibility?
options: The S-haplotype of the pollen grain itself (gametophytic genotype) determines compatibility through interaction with pistil S-RNase
Pollen tube growth rate determines compatibility—faster-growing self-pollen tubes are selectively arrested
Random methylation of SI genes during meiosis determines which pollen grains are compatible
The S-haplotype of the pollen parent (sporophytic genotype) determines compatibility because S-cysteine-rich protein (SCR/SP11) is deposited on the pollen coat from tapetum cells
questions.explanation: In sporophytic self-incompatibility (SSI) of Brassicaceae, compatibility is determined by the diploid S-genotype of the pollen-producing parent (sporophyte), not the haploid genotype of the pollen grain itself. This occurs because the pollen coat proteins responsible for the SI response are synthesized by the diploid tapetum cells (which line the anther locule) and deposited onto the pollen grain surface during pollen maturation. The key male determinant is SCR/SP11 (S-locus Cysteine-Rich protein), a small cysteine-rich peptide encoded at the S-locus that is expressed in the tapetum and deposited on the pollen coat. On the stigma surface, the female determinant is the SRK (S-locus Receptor Kinase), a transmembrane serine/threonine kinase. When SCR from the pollen coat matches the SRK on the stigma (i.e., they share the same S-haplotype), SRK is activated, triggering a signaling cascade through ARC1 (an E3 ubiquitin ligase) that leads to rejection of the pollen.

questions.question: Pollen tube growth in the pistil is guided to the embryo sac through a series of molecular signals. Which signal is responsible for micropylar pollen tube guidance in the final stage of tube growth?
options: Calcium gradient in the transmitting tissue that creates a chemotactic path from stigma to ovule
Arabinogalactan proteins (AGPs) lining the transmitting tract that provide adhesive guidance
Auxin gradient from the funiculus that directs pollen tube growth toward the ovule
LURE peptides (defensin-like cysteine-rich polypeptides) secreted by the synergid cells that attract the pollen tube to the micropyle
questions.explanation: Pollen tube guidance occurs in multiple stages with different molecular mechanisms. The final, short-range attraction of the pollen tube to the micropyle of the ovule is mediated by LURE peptides—small, secreted defensin-like cysteine-rich polypeptides (CRPs) produced specifically by the synergid cells of the embryo sac. In Torenia fournieri, where the embryo sac protrudes from the ovule allowing direct observation, LURE1 and LURE2 were identified as the attractants. In Arabidopsis, AtLURE1 peptides serve the same function. These peptides are secreted from the synergid cells through the filiform apparatus (specialized cell wall invaginations at the micropylar end of synergids) and diffuse toward the micropyle, creating a concentration gradient that guides the pollen tube tip. The pollen tube perceives LURE through receptor kinases on its tip membrane (PRK6 in Arabidopsis). Earlier stages of pollen tube guidance involve TTS (Transmitting Tissue-Specific) glycoproteins and AGPs in the style, but these provide funicular guidance, not the final micropylar targeting.

questions.question: The ABC model of floral organ identity explains how three classes of homeotic genes specify the four types of floral organs. According to this model, what gene combination specifies petal identity?
options: A function alone specifies petals in the second whorl
B function alone specifies petals in the second whorl
B + C functions together specify petals in the second whorl
A + B functions together specify petals in the second whorl
questions.explanation: The ABC model, proposed by Coen and Meyerowitz (1991), explains floral organ identity through combinatorial expression of three classes of homeotic genes across four concentric whorls: Whorl 1 (outermost): A function alone specifies sepals; Whorl 2: A + B functions together specify petals; Whorl 3: B + C functions together specify stamens; Whorl 4 (innermost): C function alone specifies carpels. In Arabidopsis, A-function genes include APETALA1 (AP1) and APETALA2 (AP2); B-function genes include APETALA3 (AP3) and PISTILLATA (PI); C-function gene is AGAMOUS (AG). The model predicts that loss of A function causes C to expand into whorls 1-2, converting sepals to carpels and petals to stamens. Loss of B converts petals to sepals and stamens to carpels. Loss of C converts stamens to petals and carpels to sepals. The model has been extended to ABCDE, with D-function genes specifying ovule identity and E-function (SEPALLATA) genes required as co-factors for all organ identities.

questions.question: Apomixis—asexual reproduction through seed without fertilization—occurs naturally in some plant species. Which mechanism correctly describes gametophytic apomixis?
options: The embryo develops from a somatic cell of the ovule integument through adventitious embryony
The zygote formed by normal fertilization undergoes polyploidization during the first cell division
Pollen grains develop into embryos through androgenesis after landing on the stigma
An unreduced embryo sac develops from the megaspore mother cell (diplospory) or a nucellar cell (apospory), and the embryo develops parthenogenetically from the unreduced egg without fertilization
questions.explanation: Gametophytic apomixis involves the formation of an unreduced (2n) embryo sac that develops into a seed without fertilization. There are two main pathways: (1) Diplospory—the megaspore mother cell itself bypasses or modifies meiosis (either skipping meiosis entirely or undergoing a modified meiosis that restores the diploid chromosome number through restitution), producing an unreduced embryo sac; (2) Apospory—a somatic nucellar cell adjacent to the megaspore mother cell develops directly into an unreduced embryo sac without meiosis, often displacing the normal meiotically-derived embryo sac. In both cases, the unreduced egg cell within the embryo sac develops parthenogenetically into a 2n embryo without fertilization, producing offspring that are genetically identical to the mother plant. Endosperm development may still require fertilization (pseudogamous apomixis) or may develop autonomously. This contrasts with adventitious embryony (option A), which is sporophytic apomixis.

questions.question: During anther development, the tapetum plays a critical role in pollen maturation. What is the primary function of the tapetum?
options: The tapetum provides mechanical support to maintain anther structure during dehiscence
The tapetum synthesizes and supplies nutrients, sporopollenin precursors, and pollen coat materials to developing microspores through programmed cell death
The tapetum produces meiosis-inducing signals that trigger microspore mother cell division
The tapetum secretes enzymes that degrade the callose wall surrounding microspore tetrads simultaneously with meiosis completion
questions.explanation: The tapetum is the innermost cell layer of the anther wall that surrounds developing microspores and plays indispensable roles in pollen development. Its primary functions include: (1) Providing nutrients (sugars, amino acids, lipids) to the avascular developing microspores; (2) Synthesizing and secreting sporopollenin precursors—the extremely resistant biopolymer that forms the outer exine wall of pollen grains. Sporopollenin is one of the most chemically resistant biological polymers known; (3) Depositing pollen coat (tryphine/pollenkitt) materials including lipids, proteins, flavonoids, and (in SSI species) SCR/SP11 compatibility determinants; (4) Producing callase (beta-1,3-glucanase) that dissolves the callose wall surrounding microspore tetrads, releasing individual microspores. The tapetum typically undergoes programmed cell death (PCD) during the later stages of pollen development, releasing its cellular contents into the anther locule for incorporation into pollen walls and coats. Tapetum dysfunction (e.g., in male-sterile mutants) results in defective pollen development.

questions.question: Endosperm development in angiosperms follows one of three main patterns. Which type of endosperm development is characterized by nuclear divisions without cell wall formation, producing a multinucleate coenocyte before cellularization?
options: Nuclear endosperm development, found in Arabidopsis and most eudicots, where the primary endosperm nucleus divides repeatedly without cytokinesis before eventual cellularization
Cellular endosperm development, where each nuclear division is immediately followed by cell wall formation
Helobial endosperm development, where the first division is cellular and subsequent divisions are nuclear
Ruminate endosperm development, where ingrowths of the seed coat create an irregular endosperm surface
questions.explanation: Nuclear endosperm development is the most common pattern among angiosperms, particularly in eudicots. After double fertilization, the triploid primary endosperm nucleus undergoes rapid, successive nuclear divisions without cytokinesis, producing a large coenocytic cell (syncytium) containing hundreds to thousands of free nuclei distributed in the cytoplasm along the periphery of the central cell. In Arabidopsis (a model for this developmental pattern), the endosperm remains coenocytic until approximately the torpedo stage of embryo development, when cellularization begins from the micropylar end and progresses toward the chalazal end through a wave-like process involving phragmoplast formation. The timing of cellularization is critical and is regulated by genomic imprinting—specifically, the FERTILIZATION INDEPENDENT SEED (FIS) Polycomb group complex. Cellular endosperm (option B) occurs in some species where each division is followed by wall formation. Helobial endosperm (option C) is intermediate, found in monocots. Ruminate endosperm (option D) describes a surface texture, not a developmental type.

questions.question: Fruit development (carpel maturation into fruit) is normally triggered by successful fertilization. What hormonal signal from developing seeds primarily promotes fruit growth?
options: Ethylene from the seed coat triggers rapid cell expansion in the pericarp
Abscisic acid (ABA) from the endosperm stimulates pericarp cell division
Auxin synthesized by developing seeds stimulates pericarp growth, and gibberellins promote fruit enlargement through cell expansion
Cytokinin from the embryo directly activates fruit maturation genes in the pericarp
questions.explanation: Fruit development is primarily driven by auxin (indole-3-acetic acid, IAA) produced by developing seeds. After fertilization, the developing embryo and endosperm synthesize auxin, which diffuses into the surrounding carpel tissue (pericarp) and stimulates both cell division and cell expansion. The auxin signal from seeds activates the expression of gibberellin biosynthesis genes in the pericarp, and the resulting gibberellins promote fruit enlargement primarily through cell expansion. Evidence supporting this model includes: (1) Seedless mutant fruits are small unless treated with exogenous auxin or gibberellin; (2) Parthenocarpic (seedless) fruit varieties often have mutations that constitutively activate auxin or GA signaling in the pericarp; (3) Application of auxin transport inhibitors to developing fruits blocks fruit growth; (4) In strawberry, selective removal of individual achenes (each containing a seed) creates localized depressions in the receptacle, demonstrating that each seed provides a local auxin source for growth. Ethylene plays a later role in fruit ripening (in climacteric fruits), not in initial fruit development.

questions.question: Seed dormancy prevents germination under unfavorable conditions. What is the primary hormonal mechanism maintaining seed dormancy in most angiosperm species?
options: High gibberellin (GA) levels in the embryo maintain dormancy by suppressing metabolic activity
Ethylene accumulation in the seed coat prevents water imbibition needed for germination
High abscisic acid (ABA) to gibberellin (GA) ratio maintains dormancy; germination occurs when this ratio shifts in favor of GA through ABA degradation and GA biosynthesis
Jasmonic acid (JA) in the endosperm blocks embryo growth by inhibiting cell division
questions.explanation: Seed dormancy is primarily maintained by a high ratio of abscisic acid (ABA) to gibberellin (GA) in the embryo. ABA promotes and maintains dormancy through multiple mechanisms: (1) ABA induces expression of late embryogenesis abundant (LEA) proteins that protect cellular structures during desiccation; (2) ABA activates transcription factors (ABI3, ABI4, ABI5 in Arabidopsis) that suppress germination-related gene expression; (3) ABA inhibits the biosynthesis of cell wall-degrading enzymes needed for radicle emergence. During dormancy release (triggered by environmental cues such as cold stratification, light, or after-ripening), ABA levels decrease through catabolism by CYP707A cytochrome P450 enzymes, while GA biosynthesis is activated. GAs promote germination by inducing alpha-amylase and cell wall-loosening enzymes in the endosperm/aleurone layer, weakening the mechanical barrier to radicle emergence. The ABA/GA ratio, rather than the absolute concentration of either hormone, is the key determinant of dormancy status.

questions.question: Pollen grains have a distinctive wall structure with two major layers. What is the composition and origin of the outer exine layer?
options: The exine is composed of sporopollenin, a highly resistant polymer of fatty acids and phenylpropanoids, primarily synthesized by the tapetum cells and deposited onto developing microspores
The exine is composed of cellulose microfibrils arranged in a species-specific pattern by the microspore cytoskeleton
The exine is composed of lignin derived from the anther wall endothecium during dehiscence
The exine is composed of cutin, identical to the leaf cuticle, synthesized by the microspore itself
questions.explanation: The pollen grain wall consists of two main layers: the inner intine (composed of cellulose and pectin, synthesized by the microspore itself) and the outer exine (composed of sporopollenin). Sporopollenin is an extraordinarily resistant biopolymer composed of polymerized fatty acid and phenylpropanoid monomers, making it one of the most chemically inert biological materials known—resistant to acetolysis, strong acids and bases, and most organic solvents. This resistance is why pollen grains are so well-preserved in the fossil record. The exine is primarily synthesized by the tapetum, the innermost anther wall layer. Tapetum cells produce sporopollenin precursors (including fatty acid derivatives processed by enzymes like ACOS5, CYP703A2, CYP704B1, and polyketide synthases PKSA/PKSB) that are secreted into the anther locule and polymerize on the microspore surface. The exine has a complex, species-specific ornamentation pattern (tectum, columellae, foot layer) that is important for taxonomic identification and for pollen-stigma interactions during pollination.

questions.question: A researcher crosses two self-incompatible plants with genotypes S1S2 (female) and S3S4 (male) in a sporophytic SI system. All F1 plants are either S1S3, S1S4, S2S3, or S2S4. When F1 plants with genotype S1S3 are used as females, which pollen genotypes would be rejected, assuming S1 is dominant over S3 in the pollen (tapetum)?
options: Only S1 pollen from S1S3 plants is rejected; all other pollen is accepted
Both S1 and S3 pollen from any plant with S1 in its sporophytic genotype are rejected, because S1 dominance in the tapetum means all pollen from S1-containing plants carries S1 coat protein
No pollen is rejected because the cross is between different S-genotypes
Only S3 pollen is rejected because the female parent is S1S3 and S3 matches
questions.explanation: In sporophytic SI (SSI), pollen compatibility is determined by the diploid sporophytic genotype of the pollen parent, NOT the haploid genotype of the pollen grain itself. This is because the S-locus determinant protein (SCR/SP11) is produced by the diploid tapetum cells and deposited on the pollen coat. When S1 is dominant over S3 in pollen, a plant with genotype S1S3 produces pollen grains that ALL carry S1 SCR protein on their coat, regardless of whether the individual pollen grain carries the S1 or S3 allele. Therefore, an S1S3 female plant (which expresses both SRK1 and SRK3 receptors on its stigma) would reject ALL pollen from any S1S3 father plant—because the S1 coat protein on every pollen grain (even those carrying S3) would activate SRK1 on the stigma. Pollen from S2S4 plants would be accepted because neither S2 nor S4 matches the female's S-haplotypes. Dominance relationships in SSI are thus critical for determining cross-compatibility in breeding programs.

questions.question: Pollination syndromes describe suites of floral traits that correlate with specific pollinator types. Which combination of floral traits is characteristic of bat-pollinated (chiropterophilous) flowers?
options: Small, white or yellow, fragrant flowers with landing platforms, opening during the day
Blue or purple flowers with ultraviolet nectar guides, moderate scent, and bilateral symmetry
Large, dull-colored (white or greenish), strong musty or fermented odor, copious dilute nectar, robust structure, and nocturnal anthesis
Red, tubular, odorless flowers with copious nectar and no landing platform
questions.explanation: Bat-pollinated (chiropterophilous) flowers display a distinctive syndrome of traits adapted to their nocturnal, large-bodied, nectar-feeding pollinators: (1) Nocturnal anthesis (flowers open at night when bats are active); (2) Large, robust flower structure that can withstand contact by relatively heavy bat visitors; (3) Dull coloration (white, cream, or greenish) since bats rely primarily on echolocation and olfaction rather than color vision; (4) Strong musty, sour, or fermented odor that attracts bats (which have excellent olfaction); (5) Copious, dilute nectar (low sugar concentration, typically 10-20%) that provides energy for the high metabolic demands of hovering flight; (6) Flowers often positioned on exposed branches or hanging below foliage (cauliflory or flagelliflory) for easy bat access. Examples include saguaro cactus, agave, banana, and durian. In contrast, option D describes hummingbird-pollinated flowers, option B describes bee-pollinated flowers, and option A describes generalist or moth-pollinated flowers.

questions.question: Genomic imprinting in angiosperm endosperm follows the parental conflict theory. How does imprinting affect endosperm development?
options: Both maternal and paternal genomes are equally expressed in endosperm, with no parent-of-origin effects
Paternally expressed genes promote endosperm growth and nutrient acquisition, while maternally expressed genes restrict endosperm growth, reflecting conflicting parental fitness interests
Only the maternal genome is active in endosperm; the paternal contribution is completely silenced
Imprinting causes all endosperm cells to be haploid, expressing only one parental allele randomly
questions.explanation: Genomic imprinting in angiosperm endosperm follows predictions of the parental conflict (kinship) theory proposed by Haig and Westoby. In this model: The paternal genome benefits from maximizing resource allocation to its offspring at the potential expense of the mother's future reproductive success (since the father may not father subsequent offspring). Therefore, paternally expressed genes (PEGs) tend to promote endosperm growth, nutrient uptake, and seed size. The maternal genome benefits from distributing resources equitably among all her offspring (current and future). Therefore, maternally expressed genes (MEGs) tend to restrict endosperm growth and limit nutrient allocation to any single seed. This conflict is mediated by epigenetic mechanisms, primarily DNA methylation and histone modifications established during gametogenesis. The FIS (Fertilization Independent Seed) Polycomb group complex (containing MEA, FIS2, FIE, MSI1) is a key maternally expressed regulator that restricts endosperm proliferation. Mutations in FIS components lead to endosperm overproliferation.

questions.question: Anther dehiscence (opening to release pollen) involves a specific biomechanical mechanism. Which cell layer and process are primarily responsible for anther opening?
options: The endothecium layer develops secondary cell wall thickenings (fibrous bands) that create differential hygroscopic tension, causing the anther wall to split along the stomium when the anther dehydrates
Enzymatic digestion of the entire anther wall by pollen-derived cellulases releases pollen grains
Turgor pressure buildup in the tapetum forces the anther to burst open explosively
Abscission of the anther tip by an ethylene-dependent programmed cell death pathway creates a pore for pollen release
questions.explanation: Anther dehiscence is a precisely regulated biomechanical process that involves: (1) Endothecium development—the endothecium, the sub-epidermal layer of the anther wall, develops characteristic secondary cell wall thickenings (fibrous bands or U-shaped thickenings) composed of cellulose and lignin during late anther development. (2) Stomium differentiation—a specialized thin-walled zone (the stomium) develops along the junction between the two microsporangia of each theca, representing the predetermined breakage point. (3) Dehydration-driven opening—as the mature anther dehydrates (water loss is accelerated by expression of aquaporin-type channels), the endothecium cells shrink differentially. The rigid fibrous bands in the endothecium resist inward collapse while the outer epidermis contracts, creating mechanical stress that is concentrated at the weak stomium, causing it to rupture. The two halves of each theca peel apart (like a bivalve shell), exposing the pollen grains. The tapetum has already degenerated by this stage and plays no role in dehiscence.

questions.question: In gametophytic self-incompatibility (GSI) systems found in Solanaceae, Rosaceae, and Papaveraceae, the S-RNase mechanism operates in the Solanaceae. How does S-RNase cause rejection of self-pollen tubes?
options: S-RNase on the stigma surface prevents pollen germination by blocking water uptake through the pollen aperture
S-RNase blocks pollen tube penetration of the cuticle by cross-linking stigmatic papilla cell walls
S-RNase enters the pollen tube and degrades ribosomal RNA in self-pollen tubes, but is inhibited by non-self SLF/SFB F-box proteins in cross-compatible tubes
S-RNase activates programmed cell death in the transmitting tissue specifically around self-pollen tubes
questions.explanation: In the S-RNase-based gametophytic self-incompatibility (GSI) system of Solanaceae (and Rosaceae, Plantaginaceae), the female determinant is S-RNase, a glycoprotein ribonuclease secreted into the extracellular matrix of the style transmitting tissue. S-RNases are taken up non-specifically into all growing pollen tubes, regardless of S-genotype. Inside the pollen tube, the fate of the S-RNase determines compatibility: In self (incompatible) pollen tubes: the S-RNase with matching S-specificity is NOT degraded and remains active, proceeding to degrade ribosomal RNA and other cellular RNA, killing the pollen tube by halting protein synthesis and disrupting cellular function. In cross-compatible (non-self) pollen tubes: multiple SLF (S-locus F-box) proteins, each recognizing a specific non-self S-RNase, function as part of SCF (Skp-Cullin-F-box) E3 ubiquitin ligase complexes that polyubiquitinate non-self S-RNases, targeting them for proteasomal degradation. This is called the collaborative non-self recognition model—a suite of SLF proteins collectively recognizes and detoxifies all non-self S-RNases.

questions.question: Seed maturation involves the accumulation of storage reserves. In a typical eudicot seed like soybean, what are the major storage compounds and where are they deposited?
options: Storage compounds (proteins in protein bodies, lipids in oil bodies, and some starch) accumulate in the cotyledons of the embryo, as the endosperm is largely consumed during development
All storage compounds accumulate in the persistent endosperm surrounding a small embryo
Storage reserves are deposited exclusively in the seed coat (testa) as a protective nutritive layer
Starch granules fill the embryonic radicle and plumule as the sole energy reserve for germination
questions.explanation: In typical eudicot seeds like soybean (Glycine max), pea, and bean, the endosperm is consumed during seed development, and the storage reserves accumulate in the enlarged cotyledons of the embryo. Soybean seeds contain approximately 40% protein (stored in protein bodies/protein storage vacuoles as glycinin and beta-conglycinin), 20% lipid (stored in oil bodies/oleosomes bounded by oleosin proteins), and modest amounts of starch and other carbohydrates. During germination, these cotyledonary reserves are mobilized by hydrolytic enzymes to fuel seedling growth until the plant becomes photosynthetically self-sufficient. This contrasts with monocot seeds like maize and wheat, where the persistent, starchy endosperm is the major storage tissue, and the cotyledon (scutellum) functions primarily as an absorptive organ that transfers nutrients from endosperm to the growing embryo. In some eudicots like castor bean (Ricinus), the endosperm persists and serves as the primary storage tissue (endospermic seed). The seed coat provides protection but does not store significant nutritional reserves.

questions.question: Pollen tube growth is one of the fastest rates of cellular elongation in nature, reaching speeds of up to 1 cm/hour in maize. What cellular mechanism drives this rapid tip growth?
options: Rapid cellulose synthesis by cellulose synthase complexes (CESAs) concentrated at the pollen tube tip

Actin filament-mediated reverse fountain streaming delivers secretory vesicles containing pectin and other wall materials to the growing tip, where they fuse with the plasma membrane to extend the tube wall
Microtubule-dependent endocytosis at the tube base creates turgor pressure that pushes the tip forward
Cell plate formation by phragmoplast assembly at the tip progressively extends the tube
questions.explanation: Pollen tube tip growth is driven by a highly organized vesicle trafficking system powered by the actin cytoskeleton. The process involves: (1) Cytoplasmic streaming in a 'reverse fountain' pattern—long actin filament bundles in the pollen tube shank drive organelles and vesicles toward the tip along the tube periphery, while material flows backward through the center. (2) An apical 'clear zone' devoid of large organelles but rich in small secretory vesicles. (3) Exocytosis of secretory vesicles at the extreme tip—these vesicles contain pectin (primarily methyl-esterified homogalacturonan), cell wall matrix materials, and new plasma membrane. Vesicle fusion with the apical plasma membrane simultaneously extends the membrane surface area and deposits wall materials externally. (4) The new wall at the tip is initially soft (pectin-rich), then stiffens behind the tip through de-esterification of pectin by pectin methylesterase (PME) and calcium cross-linking. (5) This process is regulated by a tip-focused calcium gradient, ROP GTPases (ROP1), reactive oxygen species (ROS), and phosphoinositide signaling. Cellulose is largely absent from the tip region and is deposited mainly in the tube shank.

questions.question: Microspore development involves a critical asymmetric division. What is the significance of the asymmetric mitotic division (pollen mitosis I) during male gametophyte development?
options: It creates two identical cells that both contribute equally to the mature pollen grain

It separates the generative cell (which will later divide to form two sperm) from the larger vegetative cell (which drives pollen tube growth), establishing distinct cell fates through differential gene expression
It reduces the chromosome number from diploid to haploid in preparation for fertilization
It produces a small degenerate cell that is absorbed and a large cell that becomes the entire pollen grain
questions.explanation: Pollen mitosis I (the first mitotic division of the microspore) is a critically important asymmetric division that establishes the two fundamentally different cell lineages within the male gametophyte. The microspore divides unequally to produce: (1) A large vegetative cell with diffuse chromatin and most of the cytoplasm—this cell will not divide again but will grow to form the pollen tube after germination on the stigma. The vegetative cell nucleus directs pollen tube growth and metabolism. (2) A small generative cell with condensed chromatin and minimal cytoplasm, initially enclosed within the vegetative cell. The generative cell will undergo one more mitotic division (pollen mitosis II) to produce the two sperm cells needed for double fertilization. This asymmetric division is critical because it establishes different chromatin states and gene expression programs in the two cell types. The vegetative cell expresses genes for tube growth, wall synthesis, and signaling, while the generative cell expresses genes related to cell cycle progression and sperm cell specification.

questions.question: Fruit classification is based on the origin of the mature fruit. What distinguishes an accessory fruit from a simple fruit?
options: An accessory fruit develops from multiple flowers fused together (inflorescence), while a simple fruit develops from a single flower
An accessory fruit develops from a single carpel, while a simple fruit develops from multiple fused carpels
An accessory fruit contains non-carpel tissue (such as receptacle or floral tube) as a major part of the edible flesh, while a simple fruit develops entirely from carpel tissue
An accessory fruit is always fleshy (drupe or berry), while a simple fruit is always dry (achene or capsule)
questions.explanation: An accessory fruit (also called a pseudocarp or false fruit) is characterized by the significant contribution of non-carpel floral tissue to the mature fruit structure. In a simple fruit, the edible or functional portions develop entirely from the ovary wall (pericarp = mature carpel wall). In an accessory fruit, tissues other than the ovary wall—such as the receptacle, hypanthium (floral tube), sepals, or other floral parts—contribute substantially to the fruit. Classic examples include: Apple (Malus)—the fleshy part is the enlarged hypanthium; the actual fruit (developed from the ovary) is the core containing the seeds. Strawberry (Fragaria)—the fleshy red portion is the enlarged receptacle; the actual fruits are the small achenes (dry one-seeded fruits) embedded on the surface. Pineapple is a multiple accessory fruit where the fleshy tissue derives from the fused receptacles and floral parts of many flowers in an inflorescence. Simple fruits can be either fleshy (berries, drupes) or dry (capsules, achenes, caryopses).

questions.question: Wind-pollinated (anemophilous) angiosperms have evolved specific floral adaptations. Which set of features is characteristic of wind-pollinated flowers?
options: Large, showy petals with nectar guides, copious nectar production, and strong fragrance
Small, inconspicuous flowers lacking petals and nectar, with large feathery stigmas and pendulous stamens producing abundant light pollen
Tubular, red flowers with copious nectar and no scent
Flowers with trap mechanisms that temporarily imprison visiting insects
questions.explanation: Wind-pollinated angiosperms display a distinct suite of floral adaptations that maximize pollen dispersal and capture efficiency: (1) Reduced or absent petals, sepals, and nectaries—these structures are unnecessary without animal pollinators and would interfere with wind access; (2) Large, feathery or plumose stigmas with extensive surface area to intercept wind-borne pollen from the air; (3) Pendulous, exposed stamens (often on long filaments) that release pollen into air currents; (4) Abundant, small, smooth, lightweight, non-sticky pollen grains—anemophilous species produce vastly more pollen than entomophilous species (pollen:ovule ratios can exceed 1,000,000:1); (5) Flowers often appear before leaves (in deciduous trees) to avoid leaf obstruction of pollen movement; (6) Inflorescences are often catkins (pendulous spikes) that move in wind. Examples include grasses (Poaceae), oaks (Quercus), birches (Betula), and ragweed (Ambrosia). Option A describes insect-pollinated flowers, C describes bird-pollinated, and D describes trap-pollination.

questions.question: The embryo suspensor in angiosperm seeds plays a transient but important role during embryogenesis. What is the primary function of the suspensor?
options: The suspensor physically pushes the developing embryo into the endosperm for nutrient access and transports nutrients and hormones (especially auxin and gibberellin) from maternal tissues to the embryo proper
The suspensor produces the seed coat by signaling integument differentiation
The suspensor generates the endosperm through additional rounds of fertilization
The suspensor anchors the embryo to prevent premature seed dispersal
questions.explanation: The suspensor is a transient embryonic structure that connects the embryo proper to the maternal tissue of the ovule. It serves several critical functions during early embryogenesis: (1) Physical positioning—the suspensor pushes the embryo proper into the nutrient-rich endosperm, ensuring optimal access to nutritive resources; (2) Nutrient transport—the suspensor acts as a conduit for transferring nutrients and signaling molecules from the maternal seed coat and endosperm to the developing embryo. Transfer cells in the suspensor have wall ingrowths that increase surface area for nutrient absorption; (3) Hormone production—the suspensor synthesizes and transports hormones, particularly auxin and gibberellins, to the embryo proper. Auxin transport through the suspensor establishes the apical-basal axis of the embryo; (4) In Arabidopsis, the suspensor consists of 6-9 cells and undergoes programmed cell death as the embryo matures. Mutations affecting suspensor function (such as suspensor/twin mutants) lead to embryo lethality, demonstrating its essential role.

questions.question: Vegetative reproduction allows plants to propagate clonally without seeds. Which statement about vegetative reproduction is correct?
options: Vegetative reproduction always produces offspring with greater genetic diversity than sexual reproduction
Vegetative reproduction is limited to flowering plants and does not occur in ferns or mosses

Vegetative reproduction produces genetically identical offspring but sacrifices the genetic diversity benefits of sexual reproduction, making clonal populations potentially vulnerable to environmental change
Vegetative reproduction requires pollination but not fertilization
questions.explanation: Vegetative (asexual) reproduction produces genetically identical offspring (clones) through mitotic cell divisions from somatic tissues of the parent plant. Common mechanisms include runners/stolons (strawberry), rhizomes (iris, ginger), tubers (potato), bulbs (onion, tulip), corms (crocus), plantlets (Kalanchoe), and fragmentation. While vegetative reproduction offers advantages—rapid population expansion, preservation of successful genotypes, reproduction without pollinators—it produces genetically uniform populations that lack the genetic diversity generated by meiosis and recombination during sexual reproduction. This genetic uniformity makes clonal populations vulnerable to environmental changes, new pathogens, and parasites (as exemplified by the Irish potato famine, where clonally propagated potato varieties were devastated by Phytophthora infestans). Vegetative reproduction occurs across plant groups (ferns reproduce via rhizome fragmentation, mosses via gemmae), does not require pollination, and always produces less genetic diversity than sexual reproduction.

questions.question: Seed germination requires the coordinated action of the embryonic axis and the endosperm/aleurone layer. In cereal grains, what is the signaling cascade that mobilizes starch reserves during germination?
options: Ethylene from the coleoptile activates starch phosphorylase in the endosperm for direct starch breakdown
Cytokinin from the radicle triggers amylase release from the scutellum epithelium
ABA from the seed coat activates lipase to convert stored lipids to sugars via gluconeogenesis
Gibberellin (GA) produced by the embryo diffuses to the aleurone layer, inducing alpha-amylase synthesis and secretion, which hydrolyzes endosperm starch to maltose and glucose
questions.explanation: In cereal grains (wheat, barley, rice), the germination signaling cascade begins with water imbibition, which activates the embryo. The embryo (specifically the scutellum) synthesizes gibberellins (GA3, GA1) which diffuse to the aleurone layer—a specialized protein-rich cell layer surrounding the starchy endosperm. In aleurone cells, GA binds to its receptor GID1, triggering degradation of DELLA repressor proteins via the 26S proteasome. This derepresses GA-responsive transcription factors (particularly GAMYB) that activate transcription of hydrolytic enzyme genes, most importantly alpha-amylase. Alpha-amylase is synthesized in the rough ER of aleurone cells, secreted into the starchy endosperm, and hydrolyzes starch (amylose and amylopectin) to maltose and glucose. Other hydrolases (proteases, beta-glucanases, nucleases) are also induced. The resulting sugars are absorbed by the scutellum epithelium and transported to the growing embryonic axis (radicle and plumule). ABA antagonizes GA signaling in this system, maintaining dormancy when ABA/GA ratio is high.

questions.question: Heterostyly is a floral polymorphism that promotes outcrossing. In distylous species like Primula, what morphological and physiological differences exist between pin and thrum flower morphs?
options: Pin flowers have long styles and short stamens, while thrum flowers have short styles and long stamens; legitimate pollination occurs only between different morphs due to incompatibility between same-morph pollen and pistil
Pin flowers are male-sterile and thrum flowers are female-sterile, ensuring obligate outcrossing
Pin flowers produce yellow pollen and thrum flowers produce white pollen, with no associated incompatibility
Pin flowers open in the morning and thrum flowers open in the evening, preventing self-pollination through temporal separation
questions.explanation: Heterostyly in distylous species like Primula involves two distinct floral morphs controlled by a supergene locus (the S-locus): Pin flowers have long styles with the stigma positioned at the corolla tube opening and short stamens positioned low in the tube. They produce smaller, more numerous pollen grains. Thrum flowers have short styles with the stigma positioned low in the tube and long stamens positioned at the tube opening. They produce larger, fewer pollen grains. This reciprocal arrangement (reciprocal herkogamy) promotes cross-pollination between morphs by pollinators: an insect visiting a pin flower picks up pollen from the low anthers on a body part that contacts the low stigma of a thrum flower, and vice versa. Additionally, a heteromorphic incompatibility system prevents 'illegitimate' pollination (pin x pin or thrum x thrum) through pollen tube rejection in the style. The S-locus supergene contains linked genes controlling style length, stamen height, pollen size, and incompatibility. Tristylous species (like Lythrum) have three morphs.

questions.question: Agrobacterium tumefaciens-mediated transformation is the most widely used method for generating transgenic plants. What natural mechanism does this technique exploit?
options: Agrobacterium produces a DNA virus that infects plant cells and integrates into the genome
Agrobacterium transfers a segment of its Ti (tumor-inducing) plasmid—the T-DNA—into plant nuclear DNA, where it integrates randomly; scientists replace the T-DNA oncogenes with genes of interest
Agrobacterium produces an RNA retrovirus that reverse-transcribes into plant DNA
Agrobacterium directly transfers bacterial chromosomal DNA to plant cells through conjugation pili
questions.explanation: Agrobacterium tumefaciens naturally causes crown gall disease by transferring a specific DNA segment (T-DNA, for Transfer DNA) from its Ti (Tumor-inducing) plasmid into the nuclear genome of wounded plant cells. In nature, T-DNA carries oncogenes (iaaM, iaaH for auxin synthesis; ipt for cytokinin synthesis) that cause uncontrolled cell proliferation (tumor formation) and opine synthesis genes that produce nutrients only Agrobacterium can metabolize. The transfer process involves: (1) Wounded plant cells release phenolic compounds (acetosyringone) detected by the VirA/VirG two-component system; (2) Vir genes are activated, producing proteins that process T-DNA into a single-stranded copy (T-strand); (3) VirB/VirD4 type IV secretion system transfers the T-strand complexed with VirD2 and VirE2 proteins into the plant cell; (4) T-DNA is imported into the nucleus and integrated into chromosomal DNA. For plant biotechnology, scientists 'disarm' the Ti plasmid by removing oncogenes and opine genes from T-DNA and replacing them with genes of interest (plus selectable markers), creating a vector for stable transgene insertion.

questions.question: The molecular mechanism of pollen tube reception at the embryo sac involves synergid cell death. What triggers synergid cell death upon pollen tube arrival?
options: Mechanical pressure from the pollen tube physically ruptures the synergid cell membrane
Pollen tube-derived reactive oxygen species (ROS) poison the synergid cell

The FERONIA (FER) receptor kinase on the synergid cell surface interacts with pollen tube-derived RALF peptides, triggering a signaling cascade that leads to synergid cell rupture, which simultaneously causes pollen tube burst and sperm release
Ethylene released by the pollen tube induces programmed cell death in the synergid
questions.explanation: Pollen tube reception at the female gametophyte is mediated by a sophisticated molecular recognition system. The FERONIA (FER) receptor kinase (also called SIRENE) is expressed on the surface of synergid cells. When the pollen tube arrives at the micropyle, FER on the synergid recognizes RALF (Rapid Alkalinization Factor) peptides presented by the pollen tube. This receptor-ligand interaction triggers a signaling cascade in the synergid that involves: (1) Reactive oxygen species (ROS) production by NADPH oxidases; (2) Calcium influx into the synergid cell; (3) Synergid cell death and rupture of the synergid cell membrane. The synergid cell rupture creates a physical opening that causes the pollen tube to also burst (pollen tube discharge), releasing the two sperm cells into the embryo sac. In feronia mutants, pollen tubes grow past the synergids without discharging, and multiple pollen tubes may enter the embryo sac (pollen tube overgrowth phenotype). The nta (NORTIA) gene, encoding a protein that relocates to the synergid membrane upon pollen tube contact, is also essential for this process.

questions.question: Embryo pattern formation in Arabidopsis establishes the apical-basal axis. What molecular mechanism establishes this axis during early embryogenesis?
options: Differential auxin distribution created by polar auxin transport via PIN proteins establishes the apical-basal axis, with high auxin concentration specifying the root pole (basal end)
Gravity sensing by statoliths in the zygote determines apical-basal polarity before the first division
Light signals penetrating the seed coat establish the shoot (apical) pole toward the light source
Random partitioning of maternal mRNAs during the first zygotic division determines cell fate
questions.explanation: The apical-basal axis of the Arabidopsis embryo is established through polar auxin transport mediated by PIN-FORMED (PIN) auxin efflux carriers. After the first asymmetric division of the zygote produces a small apical cell (future embryo proper) and a large basal cell (future suspensor), PIN7 protein in the suspensor cells directs auxin flow upward into the embryo proper, establishing high auxin levels apically. During the globular-to-heart stage transition, PIN1 expression switches the auxin flow direction—PIN1 in the inner cells of the embryo proper redirects auxin downward toward the basal end, creating an auxin maximum at the position of the future root meristem (hypophysis). This auxin maximum activates the MONOPTEROS/ARF5 transcription factor, which induces root stem cell specification genes. Experimental evidence supporting this model includes: pin7 mutants show disrupted early embryo development; pin1 mutants lack root meristems; auxin response reporter (DR5) confirms the predicted auxin distribution patterns. This PIN-mediated auxin flux is the primary axis-establishing mechanism.

questions.question: Parthenocarpy—fruit development without fertilization—produces seedless fruits. What hormonal treatment can induce parthenocarpy in normally seeded species?
options: Application of ABA to unpollinated flowers inhibits ovule abortion and triggers fruit development
Application of ethylene to unpollinated flowers accelerates fruit ripening without seeds
Application of auxin or gibberellin to unpollinated flowers bypasses the fertilization requirement and stimulates fruit development
Application of jasmonic acid to unpollinated flowers triggers defense-related fruit hardening
questions.explanation: Parthenocarpy can be induced by exogenous application of auxin or gibberellin (GA) to unpollinated flowers, mimicking the hormonal signals that developing seeds normally provide. In natural fruit development, seeds produce auxin (IAA) that triggers fruit growth, and auxin subsequently activates GA biosynthesis in the pericarp. By applying these hormones directly to unfertilized ovaries, the seed-derived signal is bypassed: auxin activates cell division and initial fruit growth, while gibberellins promote cell expansion and fruit enlargement. This principle is commercially exploited in agriculture: gibberellic acid (GA3) is applied to Thompson seedless grape clusters to increase berry size; auxin analogs (2,4-D, 4-CPA) are applied to tomatoes and peppers to produce seedless fruit in greenhouses where pollination is limited. Genetic parthenocarpy occurs naturally in some cultivars due to mutations that constitutively activate auxin or GA signaling in the pericarp—for example, parthenocarpic tomato lines carry mutations in SlARF7 or SlDELLA genes.

questions.question: In vitro plant propagation through somatic embryogenesis is used in agricultural biotechnology. What distinguishes somatic embryogenesis from organogenesis in tissue culture?
options: Somatic embryogenesis produces embryos directly from somatic cells that develop through stages resembling zygotic embryogenesis (globular, heart, torpedo), while organogenesis produces shoots or roots individually from callus tissue
Somatic embryogenesis requires fertilization in culture, while organogenesis does not
Somatic embryogenesis works only with monocot species, while organogenesis works only with dicots
Somatic embryogenesis produces haploid plants, while organogenesis produces diploid plants
questions.explanation: Somatic embryogenesis is the process by which somatic (non-reproductive) cells develop into embryos through a pathway that recapitulates the stages of zygotic embryogenesis—globular, heart, torpedo, and cotyledonary stages—without fertilization. These somatic embryos are bipolar structures with both a shoot and root meristem, and they can develop into complete plants. The process is typically induced in tissue culture by manipulating the auxin:cytokinin ratio, often beginning with high auxin (2,4-D) to induce embryogenic callus, followed by auxin withdrawal to trigger embryo differentiation. In contrast, organogenesis produces individual organs (shoots or roots) from callus or explant tissue: high cytokinin:auxin ratio favors shoot organogenesis, while high auxin:cytokinin ratio favors root organogenesis. The key distinction is that somatic embryos are complete bipolar structures (like seeds without seed coats), while organogenesis requires separate shoot and root induction, followed by shoot-root joining. Somatic embryogenesis works in both monocots and dicots and produces diploid plants from diploid cells.

questions.question: The integuments of an ovule develop into the seed coat (testa) after fertilization. Which property of the seed coat is most important for long-term seed viability?
options: The seed coat produces photosynthetic pigments that generate energy for the dormant embryo
The seed coat contains high concentrations of growth hormones that accelerate germination
The seed coat accumulates toxic alkaloids that repel all soil microorganisms
The seed coat provides a physical and chemical barrier against water loss, pathogen invasion, and mechanical damage, with impermeability controlling water imbibition and germination timing
questions.explanation: The seed coat (testa) is the primary protective structure that determines long-term seed viability. Its properties include: (1) Physical impermeability—the testa contains layers of thick-walled, lignified, or suberized cells (often palisade-like macrosclereids in the outer layer) that restrict water and gas exchange, preventing premature germination and protecting against desiccation. Some species (hard-seeded legumes) have nearly completely impermeable seed coats that must be scarified for germination; (2) Pathogen defense—tannins, phenolic compounds, and antimicrobial substances in the testa protect against fungal and bacterial invasion; (3) Mechanical protection—the hardened testa shields the embryo from physical damage during dispersal and soil burial; (4) Germination control—seed coat impermeability acts as a dormancy mechanism, regulating when water can imbibe and trigger germination. The seed coat does not photosynthesize, does not contain significant growth hormone stores, and does not repel all microorganisms (beneficial mycorrhizae must eventually interact with the emerging radicle).

questions.question: Pollination by deception—where flowers attract pollinators without providing rewards—is common in orchids. What mechanism does the Mediterranean orchid Ophrys use to attract pollinating male wasps?
options: Ophrys produces nectar deep in its spur that wasps cannot access, forcing repeated visits
Ophrys mimics the specific sex pheromone chemicals and visual appearance of female wasps, inducing male wasps to attempt copulation (pseudocopulation) and transfer pollinia in the process
Ophrys traps wasps inside its flower using a hinged lip mechanism, coating them in pollen before release
Ophrys produces UV-fluorescent patterns that confuse wasp navigation, causing them to land repeatedly
questions.explanation: Ophrys orchids are among the most remarkable examples of pollination by sexual deception. Each Ophrys species typically targets a specific wasp or bee species through an extraordinarily precise mimicry system: (1) Chemical mimicry—the orchid labellum (lip) produces a blend of volatile organic compounds (alkanes, alkenes, esters) that closely matches the species-specific sex pheromone of the target female wasp or bee. These compounds are perceived by the male insect's antennae; (2) Visual mimicry—the labellum color, shape, and pilosity (hairiness) resemble the body of the female insect; (3) Tactile mimicry—the labellum texture and hair patterns provide tactile stimuli similar to the female body. Male wasps or bees, attracted by the chemical and visual cues, land on the labellum and attempt copulation (pseudocopulation). During these movements, the pollinia (pollen masses) are attached to the insect's head or abdomen via the viscidium (sticky disc). When the deceived male visits another Ophrys flower, the pollinia are deposited on the stigma. This highly species-specific pollination mechanism drives reproductive isolation and speciation in Ophrys.

questions.question: A researcher wants to test whether a newly discovered protein X is required for pollen tube guidance in Arabidopsis. Which experimental approach would provide the strongest evidence?
options: Generate a protein-X knockout mutant, perform reciprocal crosses with wild-type plants, and analyze whether mutant pollen tubes fail to navigate to ovules or whether mutant pistils fail to attract wild-type pollen tubes
Overexpress protein X in leaf tissue and measure pollen tube growth on leaf surfaces
Apply purified protein X to pollen grains in vitro and measure germination rates
Sequence protein X and compare it to known guidance proteins using bioinformatics alone
questions.explanation: Reciprocal crosses using protein-X knockout mutants provide the strongest evidence for guidance function because they distinguish between male and female contributions. If protein X is required for pollen tube guidance: (1) If X functions in the female (pistil): Crossing wild-type pollen onto mutant pistils would show pollen tube guidance defects (tubes failing to reach ovules), while crossing mutant pollen onto wild-type pistils would show normal guidance. This identifies X as a female-expressed guidance cue. (2) If X functions in the male (pollen tube): Crossing mutant pollen onto wild-type pistils would show guidance defects, while the reciprocal cross would be normal. This identifies X as a pollen tube-expressed guidance receptor or response component. (3) If X functions in both: Both cross directions show defects. Additional assays include semi-in-vivo pollen tube guidance assays where excised ovules are placed near pollen tubes growing on agar, and fluorescent protein fusions to determine where protein X localizes. Bioinformatics alone cannot prove function, in vitro germination does not test guidance, and leaf expression is not physiologically relevant.

questions.question: Polyploidy has been a major force in angiosperm evolution and speciation. What is the difference between autopolyploidy and allopolyploidy?
options: Autopolyploidy involves genome duplication within a single species (e.g., 4n from 2n), while allopolyploidy involves hybridization between different species followed by genome duplication, combining two distinct genomes
Autopolyploidy produces sterile offspring while allopolyploidy always produces fertile offspring
Autopolyploidy occurs only in wild species while allopolyploidy occurs only through human intervention
Autopolyploidy involves duplication of nuclear DNA while allopolyploidy involves duplication of organellar (chloroplast and mitochondrial) DNA
questions.explanation: Polyploidy is classified into two main types based on the origin of the additional chromosome sets: Autopolyploidy results from genome duplication within a single species—for example, if a mitotic error during cell division produces a tetraploid (4n) cell in an otherwise diploid (2n) organism. Autotetraploids have four copies of the same basic chromosome set (AAAA). They may show reduced fertility due to multivalent formation during meiosis (four homologs instead of two, leading to unbalanced segregation), but many autopolyploid species are successful (banana, potato, watermelon). Allopolyploidy results from interspecific hybridization followed by genome duplication. First, two different species (with genomes AA and BB) hybridize to produce a diploid hybrid (AB). This hybrid is typically sterile because the non-homologous chromosomes cannot pair properly during meiosis. However, if the hybrid genome doubles (to AABB), each chromosome now has a homologous partner for meiotic pairing, restoring fertility. Allopolyploidy has been a major mechanism of speciation in angiosperms—bread wheat (Triticum aestivum, AABBDD, hexaploid) is a classic allopolyploid.

questions.question: Flower development is regulated by the transition from vegetative to reproductive growth. What molecular switch triggers the vegetative-to-floral transition in the shoot apical meristem?
options: Accumulation of sucrose in the meristem above a threshold concentration directly activates floral organ identity genes
Temperature-dependent degradation of a repressor protein that constitutively blocks flowering

The florigen signal (FT protein) moves from leaves to the shoot apical meristem via phloem, where it interacts with the transcription factor FD to activate APETALA1 and LEAFY, converting the vegetative meristem to an inflorescence/floral meristem
Mechanical stress from expanding leaves triggers flower development through mechanosensitive ion channels in the meristem
questions.explanation: The floral transition is triggered by the mobile florigen signal, identified as the FT (FLOWERING LOCUS T) protein. The molecular mechanism involves: (1) In leaves exposed to inductive photoperiod, the circadian clock and photoreceptors activate CONSTANS (CO) transcription factor, which induces FT gene expression; (2) FT protein (a small phosphatidylethanolamine-binding protein) is loaded into phloem companion cells and transported via sieve elements to the shoot apical meristem; (3) At the meristem, FT protein enters cells and interacts with the bZIP transcription factor FD, forming an FT-FD complex; (4) This complex activates expression of floral meristem identity genes, particularly APETALA1 (AP1) and LEAFY (LFY), which irreversibly convert the vegetative meristem to a floral meristem; (5) LFY and AP1 then activate the ABC(DE) floral organ identity genes. This florigen pathway integrates multiple environmental signals (photoperiod, vernalization, temperature, age) and is conserved across angiosperms. In rice, the FT ortholog Hd3a performs the same function.

questions.question: Seed dispersal mechanisms have evolved in close association with fruit morphology. Which fruit adaptation is correctly matched with its dispersal agent?
options: Winged samaras (maple) — water dispersal (hydrochory)
Fleshy, brightly colored drupes (cherry) — wind dispersal (anemochory)
Hooked burrs (burdock) — gravity dispersal (barochory)
Explosive dehiscent capsules (Impatiens) — ballistic dispersal (autochory), where the fruit mechanically ejects seeds away from the parent
questions.explanation: Explosive or ballistic seed dispersal (autochory) occurs in species like Impatiens (touch-me-not), Ecballium elaterium (squirting cucumber), and many legumes. In Impatiens, the fruit is a capsule with five fused valves under tension. When ripe, even slight touch causes the valves to suddenly coil inward, explosively ejecting seeds several meters from the parent plant. The mechanism involves differential turgor pressure and tissue tensions within the fruit wall—inner cell layers swell while outer layers remain turgid, building elastic potential energy that is released catastrophically when the dehiscence zone weakens. In Ecballium, internal pressure from mucilaginous fluid builds to several atmospheres, and seeds are squirted out when the fruit detaches from the pedicel. Winged samaras are adapted for wind dispersal (anemochory); fleshy drupes are adapted for animal dispersal (endozoochory—birds eat the fruit and disperse seeds in their droppings); hooked burrs are adapted for animal dispersal by external attachment (epizoochory).

questions.question: CRISPR-Cas9 gene editing has revolutionized plant biotechnology. What advantage does CRISPR-Cas9 have over Agrobacterium-mediated transgene insertion for crop improvement?
options: CRISPR-Cas9 can make precise, targeted mutations at specific genomic loci without inserting foreign DNA, potentially producing non-transgenic edited plants that may face less regulatory restriction
CRISPR-Cas9 works only in monocots while Agrobacterium works only in dicots
CRISPR-Cas9 is completely free of off-target effects, unlike Agrobacterium transformation
CRISPR-Cas9 can only knock out genes, while Agrobacterium can both knock out and overexpress genes
questions.explanation: CRISPR-Cas9 gene editing offers several advantages over conventional Agrobacterium-mediated transformation: (1) Precision—CRISPR-Cas9 makes targeted double-strand breaks at specific genomic loci guided by a short guide RNA (sgRNA), allowing precise gene knockout (via NHEJ repair introducing indels), precise base editing (using base editors like CBE or ABE), or precise gene insertion (via HDR with a donor template). Agrobacterium T-DNA integrates randomly, potentially disrupting important genes. (2) Non-transgenic products—after CRISPR reagents (Cas9 + sgRNA) make the desired edit, the Cas9 transgene can be segregated away through crossing, producing edited but transgene-free plants. This is particularly important for regulatory purposes, as some jurisdictions (e.g., Japan, USA for certain modifications) exempt gene-edited crops without foreign DNA from GMO regulations. (3) Multiplexing—multiple guide RNAs can simultaneously target several genes. However, CRISPR is not completely free of off-target effects, works in both monocots and dicots, and can be used for gene activation (CRISPRa) and repression (CRISPRi) as well as knockout.

questions.question: Pollinia are a specialized pollen presentation mechanism found in orchids and milkweeds. What is a pollinium and how does it differ from free pollen grains?
options: A pollinium is a mass of pollen grains held together by viscin threads or a waxy matrix, transferred as a single unit to pollinators via a sticky viscidium, ensuring efficient transfer of large pollen quantities in a single pollinator visit
A pollinium is a single giant pollen grain that contains thousands of sperm cells
A pollinium is a nectar-filled structure that attracts pollinators to the anther
A pollinium is a modified stamen that detaches and is carried away by wind
questions.explanation: A pollinium (plural: pollinia) is a compact, cohesive mass of pollen grains from an entire anther or anther sac that is transferred as a single unit during pollination. In orchids, pollinia are typically waxy and hard, with all pollen grains cemented together. Each pollinium is connected to a viscidium (a sticky pad) via a stalk called the caudicle (in orchids) or translator (in milkweeds). The complete dispersal unit (pollinium + caudicle/translator + viscidium) is called a pollinarium. When a pollinator (typically a specific bee, wasp, moth, or hummingbird) visits the flower, the viscidium attaches to the pollinator's body, and the entire pollinarium is removed. At the next flower, the pollinia contact the stigmatic surface. This mechanism is highly efficient because: (1) All pollen from one anther is transferred in a single visit, unlike free pollen where only a fraction is transferred; (2) Species specificity is high because pollinia must be placed and removed from precise locations on the pollinator's body; (3) Pollinia reduce pollen waste during transit.

questions.question:
Match each type of fruit with its correct botanical definition and example:
(I) Simple fruit
(II) Aggregate fruit
(III) Multiple fruit
(IV) Accessory fruit

(P) Develops from a single ovary of a single flower (e.g., peach, tomato, pea pod)
(Q) Develops from an inflorescence—multiple fused flowers (e.g., pineapple, fig, mulberry)
(R) Develops from multiple separate carpels of a single flower (e.g., raspberry, strawberry receptacle achenes excluded)
(S) Includes substantial non-carpel tissue (receptacle, hypanthium) as part of the edible flesh (e.g., apple, strawberry)
options: I-P, II-R, III-Q, IV-S
I-R, II-P, III-S, IV-Q
I-S, II-Q, III-P, IV-R
I-Q, II-S, III-R, IV-P
questions.explanation: Fruit classification is based on floral origin: (I) Simple fruit—develops from a single ovary (one or more fused carpels) of a single flower. Can be fleshy (berry: tomato, grape; drupe: peach, cherry; pome: apple core portion) or dry (capsule: poppy; achene: sunflower; legume: pea pod; caryopsis: wheat grain). (II) Aggregate fruit—develops from a single flower that has multiple separate (apocarpous) carpels, each of which develops into a fruitlet. The raspberry is a classic example: each 'drupelet' develops from one carpel of the single flower. Strawberry achenes (the 'seeds' on the surface) are also an aggregate fruit, though the fleshy receptacle makes the whole structure an accessory fruit. (III) Multiple fruit—develops from an inflorescence (cluster of many flowers), where individual fruits fuse together as they mature. Pineapple (fused berry-like fruitlets from a spiral inflorescence), fig (an enclosed inflorescence called a syconium), and mulberry are examples. (IV) Accessory fruit—includes substantial non-ovary tissue: apple (fleshy hypanthium surrounds the carpel-derived core), strawberry (fleshy receptacle bearing aggregate achenes).

questions.question: A researcher measures pollen tube growth rates in styles of different lengths in Nicotiana alata. Data shows: Short-styled mutant (5 mm style): compatible tubes reach ovules in 6 hours; Normal-styled plants (25 mm style): compatible tubes reach ovules in 18 hours; Self-incompatible tubes in normal styles: tubes arrest at 3-4 mm after 12 hours. What can be concluded about the S-RNase rejection mechanism?
options: S-RNase acts at the stigma surface, preventing pollen germination entirely
S-RNase acts throughout the style but requires a minimum distance of tube growth before the cytotoxic effect (RNA degradation) becomes lethal, explaining why self-tubes grow 3-4 mm before arrest
Self-incompatible pollen tubes grow at the same rate as compatible tubes but are physically blocked by callose plugs in the style transmitting tissue
S-RNase only acts in the ovary, and the arrest at 3-4 mm is due to nutrient depletion in the style
questions.explanation: The data reveal important features of the S-RNase rejection mechanism in gametophytic self-incompatibility: (1) Compatible pollen tubes grow through the full style length (5 mm or 25 mm) and reach ovules, indicating normal tube growth when the S-RNase is detoxified by non-self SLF F-box proteins. (2) Self-incompatible tubes grow 3-4 mm before arresting, regardless of total style length. This indicates that S-RNase enters all pollen tubes (compatible and incompatible) non-specifically as they grow through the style. In incompatible tubes, the matching S-RNase is not degraded by SLF proteins and remains active. The cytotoxic effect (degradation of ribosomal RNA and other cellular RNA by the active S-RNase) is cumulative—it takes time for sufficient RNA degradation to halt protein synthesis and kill the pollen tube. The 3-4 mm growth before arrest represents the lag period during which the pollen tube can still grow using pre-existing mRNAs and proteins while the S-RNase progressively degrades new RNA. The arrest does not occur at the stigma surface or at the ovary, confirming that the mechanism acts within the growing pollen tube during stylar transit.

questions.question: Protandry and protogyny are temporal mechanisms that reduce self-pollination within a flower. What is the difference between these two strategies?
options: Protandry means stamens and pistils develop on separate plants, while protogyny means both are on the same plant
Protandry occurs in monocots only, while protogyny occurs in dicots only
Protandry means anthers mature and release pollen before the stigma of the same flower becomes receptive, while protogyny means the stigma becomes receptive before pollen is released
Protandry involves pollen production in the morning and stigma receptivity at night, while protogyny is the reverse
questions.explanation: Protandry and protogyny are forms of dichogamy—the temporal separation of male and female functions within a hermaphroditic flower to promote outcrossing: Protandry (male-first): Anthers mature, dehisce, and release pollen BEFORE the stigma of the same flower becomes receptive. By the time the stigma is receptive to pollen, the flower's own pollen has already been dispersed to other flowers by pollinators. Examples include many Asteraceae (sunflower family), carrots (Apiaceae), and many legumes. Protogyny (female-first): The stigma becomes receptive and can receive pollen BEFORE the anthers of the same flower mature and release pollen. Early visitors to the flower deposit pollen from other plants onto the receptive stigma. By the time the flower's own pollen is released, the stigma may no longer be receptive. Examples include avocado, magnolia, walnut, and many wind-pollinated trees. Both strategies reduce (but do not eliminate) self-pollination because other flowers on the same plant may be at different stages. These are distinct from dioecy (separate male and female plants) and spatial separation mechanisms.

questions.question: Bt crops express insecticidal proteins from Bacillus thuringiensis. How does the Bt Cry protein kill susceptible insect larvae?
options: Cry protein acts as a neurotoxin that blocks acetylcholinesterase in the insect nervous system
Cry protein inhibits chitin synthesis, preventing insect molting and larval development
Cry protein is activated by alkaline gut pH and forms pores in the midgut epithelial cell membranes, causing osmotic lysis and septicemia
Cry protein suppresses the insect immune system, making larvae susceptible to environmental pathogens
questions.explanation: Bt Cry (Crystal) proteins are parasporal crystal proteins produced by Bacillus thuringiensis that are highly specific insecticides. Their mechanism of action involves: (1) Ingestion—susceptible insect larvae consume Cry protein crystals (or transgenic plant tissue expressing Cry proteins); (2) Solubilization—in the alkaline environment (pH 9-12) of the lepidopteran midgut, the crystalline protoxin dissolves; (3) Proteolytic activation—midgut proteases (trypsin-like enzymes) cleave the protoxin to produce the active toxin fragment (approximately 60-70 kDa); (4) Receptor binding—the activated toxin binds to specific receptors on midgut epithelial cells, including cadherin-like proteins and aminopeptidase N; (5) Oligomerization and pore formation—bound toxin molecules oligomerize into a pre-pore complex that inserts into the cell membrane, forming transmembrane pores; (6) Cell lysis—pore formation disrupts ion homeostasis and osmotic balance, causing cell swelling and lysis; (7) Gut breakdown—destruction of the midgut epithelium allows gut bacteria to enter the hemocoel, causing septicemia and larval death within 24-48 hours.

questions.question: The molecular mechanism of pollen hydration on the stigma surface is the first step in pollen-pistil interaction. In dry-stigma species like Arabidopsis, what regulates selective pollen hydration?
options: All pollen grains hydrate equally on any stigma surface regardless of species compatibility

Compatible pollen coat lipids interact with the stigmatic papilla cell cuticle to allow water transfer from stigma to pollen, while incompatible pollen is not hydrated due to lipid-lipid incompatibility
Pollen grains carry their own water supply and do not require stigmatic hydration
Hydration is regulated by atmospheric humidity alone, with no contribution from the stigma
questions.explanation: In dry-stigma species (where the stigma surface lacks a fluid exudate), pollen hydration is a regulated, selective process that serves as the first checkpoint in pollen-pistil compatibility. Compatible pollen hydration involves: (1) Initial adhesion—pollen coat lipids and proteins (produced by the tapetum and deposited during pollen maturation) make initial contact with the stigma papilla cell cuticle; (2) Recognition—compatible pollen coat proteins interact with stigmatic receptors, triggering localized breakdown of the papilla cuticle; (3) Water transfer—water flows from the turgid stigmatic papilla cell through the modified cuticle interface to the desiccated pollen grain, allowing it to hydrate, metabolically activate, and germinate. In sporophytic self-incompatibility systems (Brassicaceae), this hydration step is where rejection occurs: when SCR/SP11 on the pollen coat activates SRK on the papilla surface, the downstream ARC1 signaling pathway prevents cuticle modification and water transfer, so self-pollen fails to hydrate. Pollen from unrelated species also fails to hydrate due to biochemical incompatibility at the lipid-cuticle interface.

questions.question: Endosperm cellularization timing is critical for seed development and is influenced by parental genome dosage. What happens when the normal 2:1 maternal:paternal genome ratio in endosperm is disrupted by interploidy crosses?
options: Paternal excess (e.g., 2x mother x 4x father, giving 2m:2p endosperm) causes precocious endosperm cellularization and small seeds
Maternal excess (e.g., 4x mother x 2x father, giving 4m:1p endosperm) causes delayed endosperm cellularization and larger seeds
Paternal excess delays endosperm cellularization, producing larger endosperm and potentially larger seeds, while maternal excess causes precocious cellularization and smaller seeds
Genome dosage has no effect on endosperm development; only total ploidy level matters
questions.explanation: Interploidy crosses that disrupt the normal 2m:1p (2 maternal : 1 paternal) genome ratio in endosperm produce predictable developmental abnormalities consistent with the parental conflict theory: Paternal genome excess (e.g., diploid mother x tetraploid father produces endosperm with 2m:2p ratio): The extra paternal genome delays endosperm cellularization, leading to an extended period of free-nuclear division and potentially larger endosperm with more storage reserves. This results in larger seeds. From the parental conflict perspective, the paternal genome drives resource acquisition, and extra paternal dosage amplifies this effect. Maternal genome excess (e.g., tetraploid mother x diploid father produces endosperm with 4m:1p ratio): The extra maternal genome causes precocious cellularization, truncating the period of endosperm proliferation and producing smaller seeds. The maternal genome restricts resource allocation, and extra maternal dosage amplifies this restriction. These observations, first described by Nishiyama and Haig, provided key evidence for genomic imprinting in plants and the interploidy triploid block to interspecific hybridization.

questions.question: Embryo rescue is a plant breeding technique used to obtain viable plants from interspecific crosses. Why is embryo rescue necessary in wide hybridization?
options: Hybrid embryos grow too quickly and burst through the seed coat, requiring physical containment
Hybrid embryos abort because endosperm development fails due to interspecific incompatibility (post-zygotic barriers), so embryos must be excised and cultured on artificial medium before they die
Hybrid embryos produce toxic compounds that kill the mother plant, requiring early removal
Hybrid pollen is too large for the style, so embryos must be produced through in vitro fertilization
questions.explanation: Embryo rescue is an in vitro culture technique essential for wide hybridization programs where interspecific or intergeneric crosses produce hybrid embryos that would normally abort.
